Graphical abstract Due to easy dehydration of La(OH)3 to LaOOH by thermal treatment, it is challenging to prepare highly efficient Ni/La(OH)3 catalyst for hydrogenolysis reactions. Herein, Ni/La(OH)3 (Ni/La-2) catalyst is prepared by thermal reduction of NiO/La(OH)3 in hydrogen flow with vaporized water, while La(OH)3 is partially dehydrated to LaOOH without water vapor affording Ni/(La(OH)3 + LaOOH) (Ni/La-1). Ni/La-2 displays 93 % and 3 % yields of 1,2,6-hexanetriol (HTO) and 1,6-hexanediol (HDO) respectively towards C-O hydrogenolysis of tetrahydrofuran-dimethanol (THFDM) in batch reactor and high stability (200 h) in fixed-bed reactor, which is the best among the reported catalysts to the best of our knowledge. Ni/La-2 possesses pure La(OH)3 as support, enhanced dispersion of Ni species and abundant Niδ+-O-La interfaces in comparison to Ni/La-1, which results in the exceptional catalytic performances in C-O hydrogenolysis of THFDM. A fine control of reaction temperature and time is required to optimize the yields HTO and HDO in hydrogenolysis of THFDM over Ni/La-2. The water-assisted preparation method provides a new perspective for the preparation of La(OH)3 supported metal catalysts. Keywords C-O hydrogenolysis Tetrahydrofuran-dimethanol 1,2,6-hexanetriol La(OH)3 LaOOH Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Lignocellulosic biomass is one of the sustainable sources of bio-based chemicals, which has attracted great research interest from both fundamental and applied perspectives [1–3] 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) as a biomass platform compound can be selectively convert to many useful products through catalytic hydrogenation [4,5]. For instance, tetrahydrofuran-dimethanol (THFDM) are produced via simple hydrogenation by using Ni catalysts [6]. An important potential use for THFDM is produce 1,2,6-hexanetriol (HTO) and 1,6-hexanediol (HDO) through C-O bond hydrogenolysis of THFDM. HTO is a high value-added chemical or intermediate used as wetting agents, solvents, pharmaceuticals, cosmetics and polymers, also precursor for the production of HDO [7–10]. HDO is mainly used in the production of polyesters and polyurethanes, and the production of 1,6-HDO from renewable lignocellulosic feedstocks is desirable because the traditional route is environmental-unfriendly [11–14]. Bimetallic catalysts have been used in the C-O bond hydrogenolysis of THFDM [8,12,15,16]. Buntara et al. reported 84 % and 3 % selectivities of HTO and HDO respectively at a conversion of 31 % in hydrogenolysis of THFDM over Rh-ReOx catalyst [8]. He et al. reported that HDO yield was over 70 % in conversion of THFDM over Pt-WOx/TiO2 catalyst [16]. However, both Rh-ReOx catalysts and Pt-WOx catalysts suffered metal leaching [8,16]. The conversion of HMF to HTO and HDO was also studied [7,9,10,17–20]. Wu et al. reported that hydrogenolysis of HMF over Pt@Al2O3 catalyst using NaBH4 as hydrogen source provided 63 % yield of HTO [10]. Kataoka et al. reported that 42 % HTO yield was obtained over Pt5Co5/CeO2 catalyst in hydrogenolysis of HMF by using water as solvent [9]. Pomeroy et al. reported that the Ni-Ce/CaO catalyst showed 59 % HTO yield in hydrogenolysis of HMF, [20] Mu et al. enhanced HTO yield to 64.5 % by using NiCoAl catalyst in hydrogenolysis of HMF [7]. However, these reported catalysts are unsatisfactory for potential industrial use due to low catalyst stability and low yields of HTO or HDO (Table S1), it is thus desirable to develop highly stable and selective catalysts for the production of HTO and HDO. Ni/La(OH)3 catalyst has displayed good catalytic performances in selective C-O bond hydrogenolysis of tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol to 1,5-pentanediol [21–23]. This inspired us to investigate the catalytic performances of Ni/La(OH)3 catalysts in hydrogenolysis of THFDM. To prepare Ni/La(OH)3 catalyst with high activity and stability for hydrogenation or hydrogenolysis reactions, thermal reduction treatment in hydrogen atmosphere above 300 °C is generally required to create Ni nanoparticles and metal-support interfaces between Ni and La(OH)3 [24–27]. However, multiply phases of lanthanum oxides including La2O3, LaOOH, and La(OH)3 tend to interconvert under certain conditions. For instance, La2O3 is found to be unstable under ambient conditions and changed to more stable La(OH)3, [28–30] thermal treatment of La(OH)3 give rise to LaOOH or La2O3, [21,28,31] making the preparation of pure La(OH)3 supported Ni catalyst very challenging (Scheme 1 ). In order to inhibit the dehydration of La(OH)3 to LaOOH or La2O3 during thermal reduction treatment in hydrogen atmosphere, vaporized water is introduced to prepare Ni/La(OH)3 catalyst in the present work (Figure S1). It is found that the presence of water can effectively suppress phase transition from La(OH)3 to LaOOH during thermal reduction at 300 °C, moreover, dispersion of Ni species is enhanced due to the presence of more hydroxyl groups in La(OH)3 than in LaOOH. The resulting Ni/La(OH)3 catalyst displays 93 % and 3 % yields of HTO and HDO respectively in C-O hydrogenolysis of THFDM, which outperforms reported catalysts to the best of our knowledge (Table S1). 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation Catalysts were synthesized by precipitation-calcination-reduction method. Typically, Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (2.47 g, 8.5 mmol), La(NO3)3·6H2O (11.45 g, 26.4 mmol) and urea (6.50 g, 108.3 mmol) were dissolved in 100 ml of deionized water and were heat at 80 °C for 24 h. After cooled to room temperature, the resulting light green precipitate was washed with deionized water until pH = 7, dried at 70 °C for 24 h, and then calcinated at 280°C in oxygen atmosphere (20 %/80 % O2/N2) for 2 h, giving NiO/La(OH)3. NiO/La(OH)3 was treated in hydrogen gas flow (20 mL/min, >99.9 % H2) at 300 °C for 2 h. After cooling down to room temperature, the sample was passivated by oxygen (5 mL/min, 1 %/99 % O2/N2) for 12 h, giving Ni/La-1 catalyst. Similarly, Ni/La-2 was prepared by flowing hydrogen gas (20 mL/min, 99 % H2) through a bubbler that contains water at about 25 °C (Figure S1). 2.2 Catalytic measurements Conversion of THFDM or HMF was performed in a stainless-steel autoclave (25 mL) equipped with a pressure gauge and magnetic stirrer. Before the reaction, a mixture of reactant, catalyst, ethanol (10 mL), dodecane (internal standard, 30 mg) was placed in a quartz vessel. After being sealed, the autoclave was purged with hydrogen gas (99.99 %) at least three times to ensure that the system is air-free, and then was charged with a certain pressure of hydrogen gas. The stirring speed was set to be 1000 rpm/min. The reaction time commenced after reaching the set temperature. After the reaction was completed, the autoclave was cooled to room temperature, followed with the discharge of the remaining hydrogen gas. The product was then condensed and analyzed by gas chromatography (7890B, Agilent) equipped with a capillary DB-Wax column and a flame ionization detector (FID). The conversion and selectivity of products were calculated on carbon basis, as shown in the formulas below: C o n v e r s i o n ( % ) = ( 1 - M o l e s o f r e a c t a n t l e f t M o l e s o f r e a c t a n t a d d e d ) × 100 S e l e c t i v i t y ( % ) = M o l e s o f a s p e c i f i c p r o d u c t M o l e s o f c o n s u m e d r e a c t a n t × 100 Yield % = Conversion × Selectivity of a specific product Specifically, the reaction conditions for Fig. 5(a–e) are listed below. (a) Comparison of catalytic performances of Ni/La-1 and Ni/La-2: THDFM (0.5 mmol), catalyst (100 mg), EtOH (10 mL), H2 pressure (4 MPa), 180 or 160 °C, 6 h. (b) The effects of reaction temperature over Ni/La-2: THDFM (0.5 mmol), catalyst (100 mg), EtOH (10 mL), H2 pressure (4 MPa), 6 h. (c) The effects of reaction time over Ni/La-2: THDFM (0.5 mm), catalyst (100 mg), EtOH (10 mL), 160 °C, H2 pressure (4 MPa). (d) The study of conversion of HMF over Ni/La-2: HMF (0.5 mmol), catalyst (100 mg), EtOH (10 mL), 160 °C, H2 pressure (4 MPa). (e) Conversion of THFDM in a fixed-bed reactor over Ni/La-2: THFDM (in EtOH) 6 mg/mL, catalyst (2 g, granules in mesh number of 20–40), H2 pressure (3 MPa), 140 °C, liquid flow rate (0.1 mL/min), hydrogen flow rate (15 mL/min with a molar ratio of THFDM/hydrogen of about 1:4000). 2.3 Characterizations Inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectrometry was conducted using PerkinElmer ICP-OES 7300DV. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) was recorded on a PAN analytical X’pert-Pro diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation in the range of 10° − 80°. The transmission electron microscope (TEM) image of the sample was obtained on Hitachi's JEM-2100 transmission electron microscope with a working voltage of 200 kV. Thermal gravimetric (TG) analysis was conducted using METTLER TOLEDO. Sample was increased from 25 °C to 700 °C with a heating rate of 5 °C/min in N2 atmosphere. H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) measurements were conducted using Micromeritics Autochem II 2920. Each sample (100 mg) was placed in a U-shaped quartz reactor. To remove traces of water in the samples, it was purged with flowing Ar (10 mL/min) at 200 °C for 1 h and then cooled down to room temperature. Then the gas was switched to 10 % H2/Ar (30 mL/min), it was heated from room temperature to 800 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were collected on a VERTEX 70 (Bruker) spectrometer using Attenuated Total Refection (ATR) techniques. Samples were prepared by three steps, (1) heating up the mixture of catalyst, THFDM and solvent (EtOH) in nitrogen atmosphere (2 MPa) at a certain temperature in batch reactor, (2) and after cooling to room temperature, catalyst was separated and rinsed by EtOH, (3) catalyst was vacuum dried at room temperature, which was ready for IR test. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physical characterizations XRD patterns of NiO/La(OH)3 show multiply diffraction peaks that correspond to La(OH)3 (Figure S2). No peaks associated with NiO were observed, indicative of a high dispersion. Reduction of NiO/La(OH)3 in hydrogen flow at 300 °C provided Ni/La-1. As shown in Fig. 1 , XRD patterns of Ni/La-1 show that copresence of La(OH)3 (PDF#36-1481) and LaOOH (PDF#19-0656) with ratio about 2:1 estimated from peak intensity, indicating La(OH)3 transformed to LaOOH with loss of a water molecule during the reduction at 300°C; and characteristic peaks at 44.3°, 51.6°, 76.0° that are associated with (111), (200), (220) phases of metallic Ni (PDF#04-0850) are observed, which means Ni/La-1 consists of mixed La hydroxides supported Ni nanoparticles. The initial temperature of dehydration of La(OH)3 is at about 290 °C, as shown in the thermal gravimetric behavior studies of La(OH)3 below, which explains the occurrence of dehydration of La(OH)3 at 300 °C. Ni/La-2 was obtained by the reduction of NiO/La(OH)3 in hydrogen flow with tiny amounts of water vapor (which were created by bubbling hydrogen gas through water at room temperature, as shown in Figure S1) at 300 °C. Significantly, Ni/La-2 shows diffraction peaks corresponding to the phase of La(OH)3, indicating the presence of water vapor in hydrogen flow suppressed dehydration of La(OH)3 to LaOOH; moreover, the characteristic peaks of metallic Ni barely exist, suggesting the pure phase of La(OH)3 is helpful to the dispersed of Ni species. The particle sizes were estimated based on Scherrer equation, the results are shown in Table S2. Ni/La-1 had a much larger particle size (23.9 nm) than Ni/La-2 (7.8 nm). Besides, Ni loadings were determined by ICP. The results show the Ni loadings of Ni/La-1 and Ni/La-2 are about 9.0 wt% (Table S3), indicating water vapor within hydrogen flow did not result in Ni loss. TEM measurements were performed to study the phases of support and sizes of Ni nanoparticles. We must mention that both Ni/La-1 and Ni/La-2 show magnetic properties (Figure S3), which indicates the presence of large metallic Ni particles. Before putting into TEM equipment, both Ni/La-1 and Ni/La-2 were exposed to a magnet to remove metallic Ni particles that have magnetic properties, so TEM images do not provide accurate information on the sizes of Ni nanoparticles. SEM measurements were also performed but provided no vision of Ni particles (Figure S4). The high-resolution (HR) TEM images of Ni/La-1 showed the presence of both LaOOH and La(OH)3 consistent with the XRD results. Ni particles with size about 2 nm are observed, but with no clear interfacial contact with support (Figure S5). TEM images of Ni/La-2 reveal that Ni nanoparticles with a mean particle size of 4.5 nm are well-dispersed on the support, and the support consists of La(OH)3 with the absence of LaOOH (Fig. 2 c). HR-TEM images clearly confirm the presence of interfaces between Ni nanoparticles and La(OH)3 (Fig. 2d and Figure S6), because of the presence of amorphous species around Ni particles and the distortion of La(OH)3 lattice around Ni particles [32–36]. The thermal decomposition behaviors and the effect of calcination temperatures were studied (Fig. 3 ). The TG profile of commercial La(OH)3 show two weight loss, the first stage corresponds to maximum weight loss at 345°C with experimental mass loss of about 10.8 %, mainly resulting from the conversion of La(OH)3 to LaOOH by removing one water molecule (the theoretical loss is 9.5 %); the second stage corresponds to maximum weight loss at 489°C with experimental mass loss of about 4.1 %, which is mainly due to the conversion of LaOOH to La2O3 by removing another water molecule (the theoretical loss is 4.7 %). By comparing the maximum weight loss temperature (MWLT) of the first stage, it is Ni/La-1 (339 °C) < La(OH)3 (345 °C) < Ni/La-2 (354 °C), suggesting the metal-support interface in Ni/La-2 suppressed the decomposition of La(OH)3; and Ni/La-2 shows more weight loss (8.1 %) than Ni/La-1 (7.6 %), which means more La(OH)3 in Ni/La-2, consistent with XRD results. In terms of the second stage, Ni/La-2 displays a weight loss of 0.8 % at the second stage, much less than that of Ni/La-1 (2.9 %) and La(OH)3 (3.8 %), indicating the Ni/LaOOH interface that formed after the first stage was very strong that inhibited the dehydration of LaOOH. The TG profiles of Ni/La-1 and Ni/La-2 above show the metal-support interfaces affected the decomposition behaviors. Reduction behavior of Ni species was studied by H2-TPR. Generally. NiO undergoes a direct reduction to metallic Ni with no intermediate valence states, therefore, H2-TPR profiles can reflect the presence of different Ni species [21]. As shown in Fig. 4 , there are three reduction peaks assigning to α, β and γ. The α peak at below 200 °C can be assigned to the reduction of surface NiO particles, and the β peak at about 250 °C could be associated with the reduction of Niδ+ (2 < δ < 3) species which locate at the metal-support interface [21,37]. The γ peak at about 400 °C corresponds to reduction of NiO that strongly interacts with support [38]. The amounts of hydrogen consumption were listed in Table S4. By comparing the α peak, Ni/La-2 is lower in both reduction temperature and hydrogen consumption than Ni/La-1, surface NiO formed during passivation in oxygen when preparing catalyst, less amounts of surface NiO in Ni/La-2 indicates a stronger interactions of Ni species with the support that inhibited the oxidation, which is also an indication of higher dispersion of Ni species in Ni/La-2 [21]. The β peak shows a much stronger intensity in Ni/La-2 than Ni/La-1. This result means the presence of a higher content of interfacial Niδ + in Ni/La-2, which is consistent with HR-TEM images. Moreover, the β peak reduction temperature of Ni/La-2 is lower than that of Ni/La-1, allowing us to believe that the Niδ+-O-La interface and promoted an easier reduction of Niδ+ [39]. In terms of γ peak that corresponds to the NiO has interactions with support, Ni/La-2 shows a lower hydrogen consumption than Ni/La-1, indicating a lower content of NiO that has interactions with support, from another perspective, lower content of bulk NiO means more Niδ+-O-La interface formed. Besides, the total higher hydrogen consumption of Ni/La-2 (1.65 mmol/g) is higher than Ni/La-1 (1.28 mmol/g), indicating higher amounts of oxidized Ni species, which is consistent with the XRD results of Ni/La-2 showing a high dispersion of Ni species. 3.2 Catalytic performances of Ni catalysts The catalytic performances of Ni/La-1 and Ni/La-2 were compared for conversion of THFDM (Scheme 2 ), the results are shown in Fig. 5a. When reaction temperature was set at 160 °C with hydrogen pressure of 4 MPa, reaction time of 6 h and EtOH as solvent, Ni/La-1 displayed a HTO selectivity of 96 % at a conversion of 21 %, and no HDO was detected. The conversion was 100 % over Ni/La-2 with HTO and HDO selectivity of 93 % and 3 % respectively, which are the best among the reported examples so far (Table S1). When reaction temperature was set at 180 °C, the conversion over Ni/La-1 increased to 51 % with HTO and HDO selectivity of 85 % and 1 % respectively, Ni/La-2 displayed 72 % HTO selectivity and 6 % at a conversion of 100 %. These results indicate that Ni/La-2 had a much higher reaction activity than Ni/La-1 and the selectivity of products was highly dependent on reaction temperature. Besides, Other products mainly include decarbonation compounds such as 1,5-pentanediol, 1,2-pentanediol, 1-butanol, 2-butanol [8,12,20,40], which were not discussed here. The effects of reaction temperature towards the hydrogenolysis of THFDM over Ni/La-2 were then studied (with hydrogen pressure set at 4 MPa and reaction time of 6 h). As shown in Fig. 5 b, with the decrease of reaction temperature from 180 to 120 °C, the HTO selectivity increased. The HTO selectivity reached 100 % when reaction temperature set at 120 °C, the conversion was only 4 %. These results indicate that higher reaction temperature is helpful to enhance reaction activity but promotes side reactions like decarbonation. The effects of reaction time (at 160 °C and 4 MPa H2 pressure) are shown in Fig. 5c. During the reaction time from 1 h to 3 h, the conversion enhanced from 3 % to 36 % with 100 % HTO selectivity. When conversion raised up to 90 % after the 8 h reaction, the HTO selectivity decreased to 98 %; and after 16 h reaction, the HTO selectivity decreased to 91 % with an increase in HDO selectivity to 8 %. These results show lower conversion was beneficial to the maintenance of high HTO selectivity and HTO gradually converted to HDO with increased reaction time. Here, one can see that reaction temperature and reaction time should be well-controlled in C-O hydrogenolysis of THFMD over Ni/La-2. Hydrogenolysis of HMF was also investigated by using Ni/La-2 as catalyst (at 160 °C and 4 MPa H2 pressure), the results are shown in Fig. 5d. HMF was completely converted and no intermediate of 2,5-bis(hydroxymethyl)furan (BHMF) was detected after 1 h reaction, indicating HMF was quickly converted to THFDM. During the reaction time of 24 h, the yield of THFDM gradually decreased, while the yield of HTO reached the highest of 81 % and then gradually converted to HDO and decarbonation products. These results suggest hydrogenolysis of HMF over Ni/La-2 is less efficient than hydrogenolysis of THFDM over Ni/La-2. Conversion of HTO using Ni/La-2 was also studied (at conditions of 160 °C, 4 MPa H2 pressure, 6 h). It was found that the conversion was 21 % and HDO selectivity was 55 % (Table S5). This indicates Ni/La-2 was not efficient for the conversion of HTO. It was reported that the conversion of HTO to HDO is metal-acidic sites catalyzed reaction.[16] Because of the weak acidic properties of La(OH)3, Ni/La-2 thus displayed an unsatisfactory catalytic performance in conversion of HTO to HDO. The stability of Ni/La-2 for hydrogenolysis of THFDM was studied in a fixed-bed reactor. The hydrogen flow rate and the feed flow rate remained constant during the whole life of the test. During the 200 h test, the conversion kept above 95 %, the HTO selectivity basically remained in range of 80 % to 95 % and the HDO selectivity slightly fluctuated in the range to 5 % to 15 %. Noteworthily, the total selectivity of HTO and HDO basically kept about 95 % during the whole test, which mean continuous flow is helpful to suppress the formation of by-products. The used catalyst from fixed-bed was collected and was characterized. The XRD patterns of Ni/La-2-used are almost identical to that of Ni/La-2, especially the peaks that correspond to metallic Ni (Figure S6), indicative of a well-kept structure. Besides, no metal leaching was observed (Table S3). Overall, we infer the exceptional catalytic performances of Ni/La-2 are attributed to the pure La(OH)3 as support, enhanced dispersion of Ni species and abundant Niδ+-O-La interfaces. 3.3 IR studies Surface adsorption of THFDM on commercial La(OH)3 and Ni/La-2 were then studied by Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra to further study the reaction mechanism. The characteristic peaks of THFDM at 1038, 1231, 1409 and 1452, 2866 and 2918, 3325 cm−1 are assigned to the vibration of C-O, C-O-C, –CH (β), –CH2 (sp3), –OH bonds respectively (Fig. 6 a) [41,42]. The IR spectra of commercial La(OH)3 displayed a sharp peak at 3608 cm−1 that can be assigned to surface hydroxyl group of La(OH)3 and broad peaks at 1380, 1464 and 1507 cm−1 that might be associated with carbonate from air [43,44]. Adsorption of THFDM on commercial La(OH)3 (pretreated at 180 °C) was first studied for comparison. After adsorption, the vibrations of C-O, C-O-C, –CH2 (sp3), –OH bonds all blue-shifted in different values, as shown in Table 1 . The vibrations of –CH (β) mixed with that of carbonate, making the comparison difficult. The blue-shift indicates that the energy required for vibrations of these groups increased, which means the presence of chemical interactions between THFDM and La(OH)3. The successful adsorption might be associated with the basic sites of La(OH)3, which formed chemical bonds with the hydroxy groups of THFDM [21–23]. Besides, the vibrations of hydroxyl group of La(OH)3 display a red-shift of 2 cm−1 in comparison to the pristine, indicating decreased energy for the stretching of the hydroxyl group, on the other hand, it is suggestive of interactions between THFDM and La(OH)3. In terms of Ni/La-2 (pretreated at 180°C with THFDM), similar blue-shifts for the vibrations of C-O, C-O-C, –CH2 (sp3), –OH bonds and red-shift for the hydroxyl group are observed (Fig. 6b). The number of blue-shifts in vibrations of C-O, C-O-C bonds are bigger on Ni/La-2 than La(OH)3, as can be seen in Table 1, indicating the interactions between THFDM and Ni/La-2 are more stronger. We infer the metal-support interface of Niδ +-O-La played an important role in enhancing the value of blue-shifts. The adsorption on Ni/La-2 were then studied at different temperatures. The vibrations of C-O, C-O-C, –OH bonds all displayed a gradual decrease in wavenumber from 180 to 120 °C (Table 1), indicating the strength of adsorption of THFDM on Ni/La-2 became weaker. The stronger interaction between THFDM and Ni/La-2 via chemical bonds with the C-O, C-O-C, –OH groups of THFDM likely result in C–C bond cleavage that produce decarbonation products in hydrogenolysis reaction. Lower temperatures, on the contrary, are beneficial to the desorption of product, which produces high selectivity. It was reported that the hydroxyl group on the surface oxide support can boost metal migration and provide anchoring sites for metal which lead to high metal dispersion [45–48]. For instance, Fu et al. recently reported that redispersion of aggregated Cu particles occurred on enriched surface OH groups which provided anchoring sites for diffusing Cu species [47]. IR spectra were thus performed to study the contents of hydroxyl group on different catalysts. As shown in Fig. 7 , IR spectra of Ni/La-1 displayed peaks at 3609 cm−1 and 3585 cm−1 that can be assigned to surface hydroxyl group of La(OH)3 and LaOOH respectively. IR spectra of Ni/La-2 displayed one peak at 3609 cm−1 associated with the surface hydroxyl group of La(OH)3. Further observation shows that the area of peaks that correspond to hydroxyl groups (of both La(OH)3 and LaOOH) in IR spectra follows the trend of Ni/La-2 > Ni/La-1, which suggests size of Ni particles increases in this order. Size of Ni particles was then estimated by Scherrer equation according to XRD patterns. The estimated average particle size for Ni/La-1 is 17.8 nm. The peaks of Ni/La-2 correspond to metallic Ni in XRD patterns are very weak, which means a small size of Ni particles. Besides, the surface area of Ni/La-2 is much larger than that of Ni/La-1 (Table S6), which is helpful to the dispersion of Ni particles. 4 Conclusion We present the preparation of pure La(OH)3 supported Ni catalysts by the assistance of water vapor during thermal reduction of NiO/La(OH)3. The presence of water vapor within the hydrogen atmosphere inhibited the dehydration of La(OH)3 to LaOOH, which promoted the dispersion of Ni species due to more hydroxy groups in La(OH)3 and created abundant Niδ+-O-La interfaces. The resulting Ni/La(OH)3 catalyst is very effective for the hydrogenolysis of THFDM with 93 % and 3 % yields of HTO and HDO respectively and high stability (200 h) in fixed-bed reactor. Product distribution of C-O hydrogenolysis of THFDM are affected by reaction temperature and reaction time. Mild reaction conditions are helpful to the selective hydrogenolysis of THFDM to HTO, harsh reactions conditions enhance reaction activity, but result in decarbonation of HTO. This work provides insight into the rational design of La(OH)3 supported metal catalysts. CRediT authorship contribution statement Xinyu Yao: Validation, Investigation, Data curation. coredata.dc:description: Due to easy dehydration of La(OH)3 to LaOOH by thermal treatment, it is challenging to prepare highly efficient Ni/La(OH)3 catalyst for hydrogenolysis reactions. Herein, Ni/La(OH)3 (Ni/La-2) catalyst is prepared by thermal reduction of NiO/La(OH)3 in hydrogen flow with vaporized water, while La(OH)3 is partially dehydrated to LaOOH without water vapor affording Ni/(La(OH)3 + LaOOH) (Ni/La-1). Ni/La-2 displays 93 % and 3 % yields of 1,2,6-hexanetriol (HTO) and 1,6-hexanediol (HDO) respectively towards C-O hydrogenolysis of tetrahydrofuran-dimethanol (THFDM) in batch reactor and high stability (200 h) in fixed-bed reactor, which is the best among the reported catalysts to the best of our knowledge. Ni/La-2 possesses pure La(OH)3 as support, enhanced dispersion of Ni species and abundant Niδ+-O-La interfaces in comparison to Ni/La-1, which results in the exceptional catalytic performances in C-O hydrogenolysis of THFDM. A fine control of reaction temperature and time is required to optimize the yields HTO and HDO in hydrogenolysis of THFDM over Ni/La-2. The water-assisted preparation method provides a new perspective for the preparation of La(OH)3 supported metal catalysts.

coredata.dc:title: Water-assisted preparation of Ni/La(OH)3 catalyst for efficient catalytic C-O bond hydrogenolysis of tetrahydrofuran-dimethanol
